moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 e6 5: one of those cases in the Hungarian variation, where White has been waiting too long to challenge c5... there is hardly any advantage left...
moves.7... cxd4 8. cxd4: better Nxd4; White is helping Black to get even...
moves.9... Nbc6 10. Nc3 f6 11. exf6 Rxf6 12. R: a bad decision; better is dxe5 and the game is even...
moves.15... Qb6 16. f4: again, not good; best was Ne2, Qxb2, Qd3, Bxe5, Reb1, Bxd4!, Rxb2, Bxb2, Rb1, Bg7... after Bh3, b6, Black should have enough compensation for the sacrificed Queen...
moves.16... Qxd4+: of course; the main threat being Ne3 after Qxd1...
moves.17. Qxd4 Nxd4 18. Rad1 Nc6 19. Re2: White is having a hard time finding the right moves here; best is Nd3, Bd4+, Kh1, or Nf3, h6, Rd2, Na5, Rd3, Nc4, Re2...
moves.23... Rf8 24. h3 Rg5 25. Kh2 d4 26. h4 R: not too accurate; a quicker solution is Rgf5, Ne4 (Nd1, Bb5, Re4, Rd8), Rxe5, Rd2, Bc6...
moves.27. Nd1: wrong time, wrong place; best is g4, Rxh4+, Kg3, g5, Nd1...
moves.27... Bb5 28. Re2e4: not better is Rd2, Bxe5, Kh3, Bg7, Bxb7, Rc5, b3, Rc7, Be4, Rc1!...
moves.28... Rd8 29. Bh3: after Bf3, Rf5, Bg4, h5, Bh4, Kf7, follows roughly the same...
moves.31... gxf5 32. Rf4 Rd5: pawn e5 is lost, and soon two connected free Black pawns will march...
moves.33. g4 Rxe5 34. Ref1: better Rg1, Re4, Rxe4, fxe4, Re1, e3, Kg3... this loses quicker...
moves.34... Bxf1 35. Rxf1 Re2+ 36. Kg3: Kh3, Be5, gxf5, h5, fxe6+, Kxe6...
moves.36... Be5+ 37. Kf3 Re4: gxf5, exf5, Rh1, h5, and all is over... so White resigns...
